unnormalised: New Delhi, October 26 - Air quality across several Indian cities, particularly in the Indo-Gangetic plain, remains a significant environmental concern. Recent studies by IIT Kanpur indicate a direct link between prolonged exposure to particulate matter (PM2.5) and respiratory illnesses, especially among children and the elderly.

Recent studies by I I T Kanpur indicate a direct link between prolonged exposure to particulate matter (P M two point five) and respiratory illnesses, especially among children and the elderly.

unnormalised: Experts from the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) are urging citizens to be mindful of their activities, particularly during peak pollution times like Diwali (November 12th this year) when firecracker usage contributes heavily to smog. Burning agricultural residue in states like Haryana and Punjab also plays a crucial role, peaking around the 1st week of November.

unnormalised: The Air Quality Index (AQI) routinely crosses the "poor" to "very poor" category in cities like Patna and Lucknow between 06:00 hrs and 10:00 hrs daily. Initiatives like the National Clean Air Programme (NCAP), launched in 2019, aim to reduce particulate matter concentrations by 20-30% by 2024. Citizens can monitor air quality in real-time using the SAMEER app. The government is encouraging use of public transport, carpooling and promoting electric vehicles to reduce vehicular emissions contributing significantly to pollution load.
